definition:
In mathematics, [*characterisation*]{} usually means a property or a
condition to define a certain notion. A notion may, under some
presumptions, have different ways to define it.

For example, let $R$ be a commutative ring with non-zero unity (the
presumption). Then the following are equivalent:

\(1) All finitely generated regular ideals of $R$ are invertible.

\(2) The $(a,\,b)(c,\,d) = (ac,\,bd,\,(a+b)(c+d))$ for multiplying ideals
of $R$ is valid always when at least one of the elements $a$, $b$, $c$,
$d$ of $R$ is not zero-divisor.

\(3) Every overring of $R$ is integrally closed.

Each of these conditions is sufficient (and necessary) for
characterising and defining the Prüfer ring.
